editorialDecl.p: The characters are identified by idREF pointing to information in the following declarations. Hamlet Bernado Claudius Gertrude Corambus Francisco Ghost Horatio Montano Fortinbras Clown1 Laertes Marcellus Prologue Ophelia Player 1 (king) Player 2 (queen) Rosencrantz Guildenstern Ambassador Cornelius Voltemand Murderer/ Lucianus Combined Speech Clown2 Priest Gentleman

langUsage.p: The languages (other than English) which occur in the text are identified by idREF which point to the following.

div1.stage:
The Tragicall Historie of HAMLET Prince of Denmarke
Enter two Centinels.

sp.l: Stand: who is that?
It is I.
O you come most carefully upon your watch,
And if you meet Marcellus and Horatio,
The partners of my watch, bid them make haste.
I will: See who goes there.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Friends to this ground.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: And liegemen to the Dane,
O farewell honest soldier, who hath relieved you?
Barnardo hath my place, give you good night.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Holla, Barnardo.
Say, is Horatio there?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A piece of him.
Welcome Horatio, welcome good Marcellus.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What hath this thing appeared again tonight.
I have scene nothing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Horatio says it is but our fantasy,
And will not let belief take hold of him,
Touching this dreaded sight twice seen by us,
Therefore I have entreated him along with us
To watch the minutes of this night,
That if again this apparition come,
He may approve our eyes, and speak to it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Tut, it will not appear.
Sit down I pray, and let us once again
Assail your ears that are so fortified,
What we have two nights seen.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Well, sit we down, and let us hear Bernardo speak
of this.
Last night of all, when yonder star that is westward
from the pole, had made his course to
Illumine that part of heaven, Where now it burns,
The bell then toiling one.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Break off your talk, see where it comes again.
In the same figure like the King that is dead,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thou art a scholar, speak to it Horatio.
Looks it not like the king?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Most like, it horrors me with fear and wonder.
It would be spoke to.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Question it Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What art thou that thus usurps the state, in
Which the Majesty of buried Denmark did sometimes
Walk? By heaven I charge thee speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is offended.
See, it stalks away.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Stay, speak, speak, by heaven I charge thee
speak.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: It is gone and makes no answer.
How now Horatio, you tremble and look pale,
Is not this something more than fantasy?
What think you on it?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Afore my God, I might not this believe, without
the sensible and true avouch of my own eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Is it not like the King?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As thou art to thyself,
Such was the very armour he had on,
When he the ambitious Norway combated.
So frowned he once, when in an angry parley
He smote the sledded polacks on the ice,
It is strange.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Thus twice before, and jump at this dead hour,
With Marshall stalk he passed through our watch.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: In what particular to work, I know not,
But in the thought and scope of my opinion,
This bodes some strange eruption to the state.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Good, now sit down, and tell me he that knows
Why this same strict and most observant watch,
So nightly toils the subject of the land,
And why such daily cost of brazen Cannon
And foreign mart, for implements of war,
Why such impress of ship-writes, whose sore task
Does not divide the sunday from the week:
What might be toward that this sweaty march
Doth make the night joint labourer with the day,
Who is it that can inform me?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Marry that can I, at least the whisper goes so,
Our late King, who as you know was by Fortenbrasse
of Norway,
Thereto pricked on by a most emulous cause, dared to
The combat, in which our valiant Hamlet,
For so this side of our known world esteemed him,
Did slay this Fortenbrasse,
Who by a seal compact well ratified, by law
And heraldry, did forfeit with his life all those
His lands which he stood seized of by the conqueror,
Against the which a moiety competent,
Was gauged by our King:
Now sir, young Fortenbrasse,
Of unapproved mettle hot and full,
Hath in the skirts of Norway here and there,
Sharked up a sight of lawless Resolutes
For food and diet to some enterprise,
That hath a stomach in it: and this (I take it) is the
Chief head and ground of this our watch.
But lo, behold, see where it comes again,
I will cross it, though it blast me: stay illusion,
If there be any good thing to be done,
That may do ease to thee, and grace to me,
Speak to me.
If thou art privy to thy countries fate,
Which haply foreknowing may prevent, O speak to me,
Or if thou hast extorted in thy life,
Or hoarded treasure in the womb of earth,
For which they say you Spirits oft walk in death, speak
to me, stay and speak, speak, stop it Marcellus.
It is here.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It is here.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: It is gone, O we do it wrong, being so majestical,
to offer it the show of violence,
For it is as the air invulnerable,
And our vain blows malicious mockery.
It was about to speak when the Cock crew.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: And then it faded like a guilty thing,
Upon a fearful summons: I have heard
The Cock, that is the trumpet to the morning,
Doth with his early and shrill crowing throat,
Awake the god of day, and at his sound,
Whether in earth or air, in sea or fire,
The extravagant and erring spirit hies
To his confines, and of the truth hereof
This present object made probation.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: It faded on the crowing of the Cock,
Some say, that ever against that season comes,
Wherein our Saviour's birth is celebrated,
The bird of dawning singeth all night long,
And then they say, no spirit dare walk abroad,
The nights are wholesome, then no planet strikes,
No Fairy takes, nor Witch hath power to charm,
So gracious, and so hallowed is that time.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: So have I heard, and do in part believe it:
But see the Sun in russet mantle clad,
Walks over the dew of yon hie mountain top,
Break we our watch up, and by my advise,
Let us impart what we have seen tonight
Unto young Hamlet: for upon my life
This Spirit dumb to us will speak to him:
Do you consent, we shall acquaint him with it,
As needful in our love, fitting our duty?

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: Let us do it I pray, and I this morning know,
Where we shall find him most conveniently.

div1.stage: Enter King, Queene, Hamlet, Leartes, Corambis, and the two Ambassadors, with Attendants.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Lords, we here have writ to Fortenbrasse,
Nephew to old Norway, who impudent
And bed-rid, scarcely hears of this his
Nephews purpose: and We here dispatch
Young good Cornelia, and you Voltemar
For bearers of these greetings to old
Norway, giving to you no further personal power
To business with the King,
Than those related articles do show:
Farewell, and let your haste commend your duty.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: In this and all things will we show our duty.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: We doubt nothing, heartily farewell:
And now Leartes, what is the news with you?
You said you had a suit what is it Leartes?

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: My gracious Lord, your favourable licence,
Now that the funeral rites are all performed,
I may have leave to go again to France,
For though the favour of your grace might stay me,
Yet something is there whispers in my heart,
Which makes my mind and spirits bend all for France .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Have you your fathers leave, Leartes?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: He hath, my lord, wrung from me a forced grant,
And I beseech you grant your Highness leave.

sp.speaker: Kiug
sp.l: With all our heart, Leartes fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I in all love and duty take my leave.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: And now princely Son Hamlet,
What means these sad and melancholy moods?
For your intent going to Wittenberg,
We hold it most unmeet and unconuenient,
Being the Joy and half heart of your mother.
Therefore let me entreat you stay in Court,
All Denmark's hope our cousin and dearest Son.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My lord, it is not the sable suit I wear:
No nor the tears that still stand in my eyes,
Nor the distracted haviour in the visage,
Nor all together mixed with outward semblance,
Is equal to the sorrow of my heart,
Him have I lost I must of force forgo,
These but the ornaments and suits of woe.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: This shows a loving care in you, Son Hamlet,
But you must think your father lost a father,
That father dead, lost his, and so shall be until the
General ending. Therefore cease laments,
It is a fault against heaven, fault against the dead,
A fault against nature, and in reasons
Common course most certain,
None lives on earth, but he is born to die.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Let not thy mother lose her prayers Hamlet,
Stay here with us, go not to Wittenberg .

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I shall in all my best obey you madam.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Spoke like a kind and a most loving Son,
And there is no health the King shall drink today,
But the great Canon to the clouds shall tell
The rouse the King shall drink unto Prince Hamlet .

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O that this too much grieved and sallied flesh
Would melt to nothing, or that the universal
Globe of heaven would turn all to a Chaos!
O God, within two months; no not two: married,
Mine uncle: O let me not think of it,
My fathers brother: but no more like
My father, than I to Hercules .
Within two months, ere yet the salt of most
Unrighteous tears had left their flushing
In her galled eyes: she married, O God, a beast
Devoid of reason would not have made
Such speed: Frailty, thy name is Woman,
Why she would hang on him, as if increase
Of appetite had grown by what it looked on.
O wicked wicked speed, to make such
Dexterity to incestuous sheets,
Ere yet the shoes were old,
The which she followed my dead fathers corse
Like Nyobe, all tears: married, well it is not,
Nor it cannot come to good:
But break my heart, for I must hold my tongue.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Health to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am very glad to see you, (Horatio) or I much
forget myself.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The same my Lord, and your poor servant ever.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O my good friend, I change that name with you:
but what make you from Wittenberg Horatio ?
Marcellus.

sp.speaker: Marc.
sp.l: My good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am very glad to see you, good even sirs:
But what is your affair in Elsenoure?
We will teach you to drink deep ere you depart.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A truant disposition, my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nor shall you make me truster
Of your own report against yourself:
Sir, I know you are no truant:
But what is your affair in Elsenoure?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My good Lord, I came to see your fathers funeral.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O I pre thee do not mock me fellow studient,
I think it was to see my mothers wedding.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Indeed my Lord, it followed hard upon.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Thrift, thrift, Horatio, the funeral baked meats
Did coldly furnish forth the marriage tables,
Would I had met my dearest foe in heaven
Ere ever I had seen that day Horatio ;
O my father, my father, methinks I see my father.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Where my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why, in my minds eye Horatio .

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I saw him once, he was a gallant King.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: He was a man, take him for all in all,
I shall not look upon his like again.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Lord, I think I saw him yesternight,

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Saw, who?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Lord, the King your father.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ha, ha, the King my father kee you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Season your admiration for a while
With an attentive ear, till I may deliver,
Upon the witness of these Gentlemen
This wonder to you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: For Gods love let me hear it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Two nights together had these Gentlemen,
Marcellus and Bernardo, on their watch,
In the dead vast and middle of the night.
Been thus encountered by a figure like your father,
Armed to point, exactly Cap-a-pe
Appears before them thrice, he walks
Before their weak and fear oppressed eyes
Within his truncheon's length,
While they distilled almost to jelly.
With the act of fear stands dumb,
And speak not to him: this to me
In dreadful secrecy impart they did.
And I with them the third night kept the watch,
Where as they had delivered form of the thing.
Each part made true and good,
The Apparition comes: I knew your father,
These hands are not more like.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is very strange.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: As I do live, my honoured lord, it is true,
And we did think it right done,
In our duty to let you know it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Where was this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lord, upon the platform where we watched.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Did you not speak to it?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Lord we did, but answer made it none,
Yet once methought it was about to speak,
And lifted up his head to motion,
Like as he would speak, but even then
The morning cock crew loud, and in all haste,
It shrunk in haste away, and vanished
Our sight.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Indeed, indeed sirs, but this troubles me:
Hold you the watch tonight?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Armed say ye?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Armed my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: From top to toe?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My good Lord, from head to foot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why then saw you not his face?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O yes my Lord, he wore his beaver up.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How looked he, frowningly?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: A countenance more in sorrow than in anger.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Pale, or red?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Nay, very pal

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And fixed his eyes upon you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Most constantly.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I would I had been there.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It would a much amazed you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yea very like, very like, staid it long?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: While one with moderate pace
Might tell a hundred.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: O longer, longer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: His beard was grizzled, no.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It was as I have seen it in his life,
A sable silver.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will watch tonight, perchance it will walk again.

sp.speaker: Hor
sp.l: I warrant it will.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: If it assume my noble fathers person,
I will speak to it, if hell itself should gape,
And bid me hold my peace, Gentlemen,
If you have hither concealed this sight,
Let it be tenable in your silence still,
And whatsoever else shall chance tonight,
Give it an understanding, but no tongue,
I will requite your loves, so fare you well,
Upon the platform, betwixt eleven and twelve,
I will visit you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Our duties to your honour.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O your loves, your loves, as mine to you,
Farewell, my fathers spirit in Arms,
Well, all is not well. I doubt some foul play,
Would the night were come,
Till then, sit still my soul, foul deeds will rise
Though all the world overwhelm them to men's eyes.

sp.speaker: Leart.
sp.l: My necessaries are embarked, I must aboard,
But ere I part, mark what I say to thee:
I see Prince Hamlet makes a show of love
Beware Ofelia, do not trust his vows,
Perhaps he loves you now, and now his tongue,
Speaks from his heart, but yet take heed my sister,
The Chariest maid is prodigal enough,
If she unmask her beauty to the Moon.
Virtue itself scapes not calumnious thoughts,
Believe it Ofelia, therefore keep aloof
Lest that he trip thy honour and thy fame.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Brother, to this I have lent attentive ear,
And doubt not but to keep my honour firm,
But my dear brother, do not you
Like to a cunning Sophister,
Teach me the path and ready way to heaven,
While you forgetting what is said to me,
Yourself, like to a careless libertine
Doth give his heart, his appetite at full,
And little recks how that his honour dies.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No, fear it not my dear Ofelia,
Here comes my father, occasion smiles upon a second leave.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Yet here Leartes? aboard, aboard, for shame,
The wind sits in the shoulder of your sail,
And you are staid for, there my blessing with thee
And these few precepts in thy memory.
"Be thou familiar, but by no means vulgar;
"Those friends thou hast, and their adoptions tried,
"Grapple them to thee with a hoop of steel,
"But do not dull the palm with entertain,
"Of every new unfledged courage,
"Beware of entrance into a quarrel; but being in,
"Bear it that the opposed may beware of thee,
"Costly thy apparel, as thy purse can buy.
"But not expressed in fashion,
"For the apparel oft proclaims the man.
And they of France of the chief rank and station
Are of a most select and general chief in that:
"This above all, to thy own self be true,
And it must follow as the night the day,
Thou canst not then be false to anyone,
Farewell, my blessing with thee.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: I humbly take my leave, farewell Ofelia,
And remember well what I have said to you.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: It is already locked within my heart,
And you yourself shall keep the key of it.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What is it Ofelia he hath said to you?

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Something touching the prince Hamlet .

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Marry well thought on, it is given me to understand,
That you have been too prodigal of your maiden presence
Unto Prince Hamlet, if it be so,
As so it is given to me, and that in way of caution
I must tell you; you do not understand yourself
So well as befits my honour, and your credit.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: My lord, he hath made many tenders of his love
to me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Tenders, Aye, Aye, tenders you may call them.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: And withal, such earnest vows.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Springs to catch woodcocks,
What, do not I know when the blood doth burn,
How prodigal the tongue lends the heart vows,
In brief, be more scanter of your maiden presence,
Or tendering thus you will tender me a fool.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: I shall obey my lord in all I may.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Ofelia, receive none of his letters,
"For lover's lines are snares to entrap the heart;
"Refuse his tokens, both of them are keys
To unlock Chastity unto Desire;
Come in Ofelia, such men often prove,
"Great in their words, but little in their love.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: I will my lord.

div1.stage:
exeunt.
Enter Hamlet, Horatio, and Marcellus .

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The air bites shrewd; it is an eager and
An nipping wind, what hour is it?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: I think it lacks of twelve,

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, it is struck.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Indeed I heard it not, what doth this mean my lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O the king doth wake tonight, and takes his rouse,
Keep wassail, and the swaggering up-spring reels,
And as he dreams, his draughts of rhenish down,
The kettle, drum, and trumpet, thus bray out,
The triumphs of his pledge.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Is it a custom here?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye marry is it and though I am
Native here, and to the manner born,
It is a custom, more honoured in the breach,
Than in the observance.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Look my Lord, it comes.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Angels and Ministers of grace defend us,
Be thou a spirit of health, or goblin damned,
Bring with thee airs from heaven, or blasts from hell:
Be thy intents wicked or charitable,
Thou comest in such questionable shape,
That I will speak to thee,
I will call thee Hamlet, King, Father, Royal Dane,
O answer me, let me not burst in ignorance,
But say why thy canonised bones hearsed in death
Have burst their ceremonies: why thy Sepulchre,
In which we saw thee quietly interred,
Hath burst his ponderous and marble Jaws,
To cast thee up again: what may this mean,
That thou, dead corse, again in complete steel,
Revisits thus the glimpses of the Moon,
Making night hideous, and we fools of nature,
So horridly to shake our disposition,
With thoughts beyond the reaches of our souls?
Say, speak, wherefore, what may this mean?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: It beckons you, as though it had something
To impart to you alone.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Look with what courteous action
It waves you to a more removed ground,
But do not go with it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No, by no means my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It will not speak, then will I follow it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What if it tempt you toward the flood my Lord.
That buckles over his base, into the sea,
And there assume some other horrible shape,
Which might deprive your sovereignty of reason,
And drive you into madness: think of it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Still am I called, go on, I will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My Lord, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why what should be the fear?
I do not set my life at a pin's fee,
And for my soul, what can it do to that?
Being a thing immortal, like itself,
Go on, I will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My Lord be ruled, you shall not go.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My fate cries out, and makes each petty artery
As hardy as the Nemeon Lion's nerve,
Still am I called, unhand me gentlemen;
By heaven I will make a ghost of him that lets me,
Away I say, go on, I will follow thee.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He waxeth desperate with imagination.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Something is rotten in the state of Denmark .

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Have after; to what issue will this sort?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Let us follow, it is not fit thus to obey him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will go no farther, whither wilt thou lead me?

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Mark me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: I am thy fathers spirit, doomed for a time
To walk the night, and all the day
Confined in flaming fire,
Till the foul crimes done in my days of Nature
Are purged and burnt away.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Alas poor Ghost.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Nay pity me not, but to my unfolding
Lend thy listening ear, but that I am forbid
To tell the secrets of my prison house
I would a tale unfold, whose lightest word
Would harrow up thy soul, freeze thy young blood,
Make thy two eyes like stars start from their spheres,
Thy knotted and combined locks to part,
And each particular hair to stand on end
Like quills upon the fretful Porpentine,
But this same blazon must not be, to ears of flesh and blood
Hamlet, if ever thou didst thy dear father love.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O God.

sp.speaker: Gho.
sp.l: Revenge his foul, and most unnatural murder:

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Murder.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Yea, murder in the highest degree,
As in the least it is bad,
But mine most foul, beastly, and unnatural.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Haste me to know it, that with wings as swift as
meditation, or the thought of it, may sweep to my revenge.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: O I find thee apt, and duller shouldst thou be
Than the fat weed which roots itself in ease
On Lethe wharf: brief let me be.
It is given out, that sleeping in my orchard,
A Serpent stung me; so the whole ear of Denmark
Is with a forged Process of my death rankly abused:
But know thou noble Youth: he that did sting
Thy fathers heart, now wears his Crown.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O my prophetic soul, my uncle! my uncle!

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Yea he, that incestuous wretch, won to his will with gifts,
O wicked will, and gifts! that have the power
So to seduce my most seeming virtuous Queen,
But vertue, as it never will be moved,
Though Lewdness court it in a shape of heaven,
So Lust, though to a radiant angle linked,
Would fate itself from a celestial bed,
And prey on garbage: but soft, methinks
I sent the mornings air, brief let me be,
Sleeping within my Orchard, my custom always
In the after noon, upon my secure hour
Thy uncle came, with juice of Hebona
In a vial, and through the porches of my ears
Did power the leprous distilment, whose effect
Hold such an enmity with blood of man,
That swift as quicksilver, it posteth through
The natural gates and allies of the body,
And turns the thin and wholesome blood
Like eager droppings into milk.
And all my smooth body, barked, and tottered over.
Thus was I sleeping by a brothers hand
Of Crown, of Queen, of life, of dignity
At once deprived, no reckoning made of,
But sent unto my grave,
With all my accounts and sins upon my head,
O horrible, most horrible!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O God!

sp.speaker: ghost
sp.l: If thou hast nature in thee, bear it not,
But howsoever, let not thy heart
Conspire against thy mother aught,
Leave her to heaven,
And to the burthen that her conscience bears.
I must be gone, the Glowworm shows the Martin
To be near, and gin's to pale his uneffectual fire:
Hamlet adieu, adieu, adieu: remember me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O all you host of heaven! O earth, what else?
And shall I couple hell; remember thee?
Yes thou poor Ghost; from the tables
Of my memory, I will wipe away all saws of Books,
All trivial fond conceits
That ever youth, or else observance noted,
And thy remembrance, all alone shall sit.
Yes, yes, by heaven, a damned pernicious villain,
Murderous, bawdy, smiling damned villain,
(My tables) meet it is I set it down,
That one may smile, and smile, and be a villain;
At least I am sure, it may be so in Denmark .
So uncle, there you are, there you are.
Now to the words; it is adieu adieu: remember me,
So it is enough I have sworn.

sp.speaker: Hor
sp.l: My lord, my lord.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lord Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Ill, lo, lo, ho, ho.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ill, lo, lo, so, ho, so, come boy, come.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Heavens secure him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: How is it my noble lord?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: What news my lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O wonderful, wonderful.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good my lord tell it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No not I, you will reveal it.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Not I my Lord by heaven.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How say you then? would heart of man
Once think it? but you will be secret.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: Aye: by heaven, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: There is never a villain dwelling in all Denmark,
But he is an arrant knave.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: There need no Ghost come from the grave to tell
you this.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Right, you are in the right, and therefore
I hold it meet without more circumstance at all,
We shake hands and part; you as your business
And desires shall lead you: for look you,
Every man hath business, and desires, such
As it is, and for my own poor part, I will go pray.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: These are but wild and whirling words, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I am sorry they offend you; heartily, yes faith heartily.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: There is no offence my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yes by Saint Patrick but there is Horatio,
And much offence too, touching this vision,
It is an honest ghost, that let me tell you,
For your desires to know what is between us,
Overmaster it as you may:
And now kind friends, as you are friends,
Scholars and gentlemen,
Grant me one poor request.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: What is it my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Never make known what you have seen tonight

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.l: My lord, we will not.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay but swear.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: In faith my Lord not I.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nor I my Lord in faith.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay upon my sword, indeed upon my sword.

sp.speaker: Gho.
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Ha, ha, come you here, this fellow in the cellarage,
Here consent to swear.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Propose the oath my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Never to speak what you have seen tonight,
Swear by my sword.

sp.speaker: Gost.
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hic & vbique ; nay then we will shift our ground:
Come hither Gentlemen, and lay your hands
Again upon this sword, never to speak
Of that which you have seen, swear by my sword.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Swear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Well said old Mole, canst work in the earth?
so fast, a worthy Pioneer, once more remove.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Day and night, but this is wondrous strange.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And therefore as a stranger give it welcome,
There are more things in heaven and earth Horatio,
Than are Dreamed of, in your philosophy,
But come here, as before you never shall
How strange or odd soever I bear myself,
As I perchance hereafter shall think meet,
To put an Antic disposition on,
That you at such times seeing me, never shall
With Arms, encumbered thus, or this head shake,
Or by pronouncing some undoubtful phrase,
As well well, we know, or we could and if we would,
Or there be, and if they might, or such ambiguous:
Giving out to note, that you know aught of me,
This not to do, so grace, and mercy
At your most need help you, swear

sp.speaker: Ghost.
sp.l: swear.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Rest, rest, perturbed spirit: so gentlemen,
In all my love I do commend me to you,
And what so poor a man as Hamlet may,
To pleasure you, God willing shall not want,
Nay come let us go together,
But still your fingers on your lips I pray,
The time is out of joint, O cursed spite,
That ever I was born to set it right,
Nay come let us go together.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Montano, here, these letters to my son,
And this same money with my blessing to him,
And bid him ply his learning good Montano .

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: You shall do very well Montano, to say thus,
I knew the gentleman, or know his father,
To inquire the manner of his life,
As thus; being amongst his acquaintance,
You may say, you saw him at such a time, mark you me,
At game, or drinking, swearing, or drabbing,
You may go so far.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My lord, that will impeach his reputation.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I faith not a whit, no not a whit,
Now haply he closeth with you in the consequence,
As you may bridle it not disparage him a jot.
What was I about to say,

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: He closeth with him in the consequence.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Aye, you say right, he closeth with him thus,
This will he say, let me see what he will say,
Marry this, I saw him yesterday, or tother day,
Or then, or at such a time, a dicing,
Or at Tennis, I or drinking drunk, or entering
Of a house of lightness viz. brothel,
Thus sir do we that know the world, being men of reach,
By indirections, find directions forth,
And so shall you my son; you have me, have you not?

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I have my lord.

sp.speaker: Cor
sp.l: Well, fare you well, commend me to him.

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: I will my lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And bid him ply his music

sp.speaker: Mon.
sp.l: My lord I will.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Farewell, how now Ofelia, what is the news with you?

sp.speaker: Ofe.
sp.l: O my dear father, such a change in nature,
So great an alteration in a Prince,
So pitiful to him, fearful to me,
A maidens eye never looked on.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why what is the matter my Ofelia ?

sp.speaker: Of.
sp.l: O young Prince Hamlet, the only flower of Denmark,
He is bereft of all the wealth he had,
The Jewel that adorned his feature most
Is filched and stolen away, his wit has bereft him,
He found me walking in the gallery all alone,
There comes he to me, with a distracted look,
His garters lagging down, his shoes untied,
And fixed his eyes so steadfast on my face,
As if they had vowed, this is their latest object.
Small while he stood, but gripes me by the wrist,
And there he holds my pulse till with a sigh
He doth unclasp his hold, and parts away
Silent, as is the mid time of the night:
And as he went, his eye was still on me,
For thus his head over his shoulder looked,
He seemed to find the way without his eyes:
For out of doors he went without their help,
And so did leave me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Mad for thy love,
What have you given him any cross words of late?

sp.speaker: Ofelia
sp.l: I did repel his letters, deny his gifts,
As you did charge me.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why that hath made him mad:
By heaven it is as proper for our age to cast
Beyond ourselves, as it is for the younger sort
To leave their wantonness. Well, I am sorry
That I was so rash: but what remedy?
Let us to the King, this madness may prove,
Though wild a while, yet more true to thy love.

div1.stage:
exeunt.
Enter King and Queene, Rossencraft, and Gilderstone.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Right noble friends, that our dear cousin Hamlet
Hath lost the very heart of all his sense,
It is most right, and we most sorry for him:
Therefore we do desire, even as you tender
Our care to him, and our great love to you,
That you will labour but to wring from him
The cause and ground of his distemperancy.
Do this, the king of Denmark shall be thankful.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My Lord, whatsoever lies within our power
Your majesty may more command in words
Than use persuasions to your liege men, bound
By love, by duty, and obedience.

sp.speaker: Guil.
sp.l: What we may do for both your Majesties
To know the grief troubles the Prince your son,
We will endeavour all the best we may,
So in all duty do we take our leave.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thanks Guilderstone, and gentle Rossencraft.

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: Thanks Rossencraft, and gentle Gilderstone.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My Lord, the Ambassadors are joyfully
Returned from Norway .

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thou still hast been the father of good news.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Have I my Lord? I assure your grace,
I hold my duty as I hold my life,
Both to my God, and to my sovereign King:
And I believe, or else this brain of mine
Hunts not the train of policy so well
As it had wont to do, but I have found
The very depth of Hamlets lunacy.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: God grant he hath.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now Voltemar, what from our brother Norway ?

sp.speaker: Volt.
sp.l: Most fair returns of greetings and desires,
Upon our first he sent forth to suppress
His nephews levies, which to him appeared
To be a preparation against the Polack:
But better looked into, he truly found
It was against your Highness, whereat grieved,
That so his sickness, age, and impotence,
Was falsely borne in hand, sends out arrests
On Fortenbrasse, which he in brief obeys,
Receives rebuke from Norway: and in fine,
Makes vow before his uncle, never more
To give the assay of Arms against your Majesty,
Whereon old Norway overcome with joy,
Gives him three thousand crowns in annual fee,
And his Commission to employ those soldiers,
So levied as before, against the Polack,
With an entreaty herein further shown,
That it would please you to give quiet pass
Through your dominions, for that enterprise
On such regards of safety and allowances
As therein are set down.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It likes us well, and at fit time and leisure
We will read and answer these his Articles,
Mean time we thank you for your well
Took labour: go to your rest, at night we will feast together:
Right welcome home.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: This business is very well dispatched.
Now my Lord, touching the young Prince Hamlet,
Certain it is that he is mad: mad let us grant him then:
Now to know the cause of this effect,
Or else to say the cause of this defect,
For this effect defective comes by cause.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Good my Lord be brief.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam I will: my Lord, I have a daughter,
Have while she is mine: for that we think
Is surest, we often lose: now to the Prince.
My Lord, but note this letter,
The which my daughter in obedience
Delivered to my hands.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Read it my Lord.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Mark my Lord.
Doubt that in earth is fire,
Doubt that the stars do move,
Doubt truth to be a liar,
But do not doubt I love.
To the beautiful Ofelia :
Thine ever the most unhappy Prince Hamlet .
My Lord, what do you think of me?
I, or what might you think when I saw this?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: As of a true friend and a most loving subject.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I would be glad to prove so.
Now when I saw this letter, thus I bespake my maiden:
Lord Hamlet is a Prince out of your star,
And one that is unequal for your love:
Therefore I did command her refuse his letters,
Deny his tokens, and to absent herself.
She as my child obediently obeyed me.
Now since which time, seeing his love thus crossed,
Which I took to be idle, and but sport,
He straightway grew into a melancholy,
From that unto a fast, then unto distraction,
Then into a sadness, from that unto a madness,
And so by continuance, and weakness of the brain
Into this frenzy, which now possesseth him:
And if this be not true, take this from this.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Think you it is so?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: How? so my Lord, I would very fain know
That thing that I have said it is so, positively,
And it hath fallen out otherwise.
Nay, if circumstances lead me on,
I will find it out, if it were hid
As deep as the centre of the earth.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: how should we try this same?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Marry my good lord thus,
The Princes walk is here in the gallery,
There let Ofelia, walk until he comes:
Yourself and I will stand close in the study,
There shall you hear the effect of all his heart,
And if it prove any otherwise than love,
Then let my censure fail an other time.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: see where he comes poring upon a book.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam, will it please your grace
To leave us here?

sp.speaker: Que.
sp.l: With all my heart.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: And here Ofelia, read you on this book,
And walk aloof, the King shall be unseen.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: To be, or not to be, Aye there is the point,
To Die, to sleep, is that all? Aye all:
No, to sleep, to dream, Aye marry there it goes,
For in that dream of death, when we awake,
And borne before an everlasting Judge,
From whence no passenger ever returned,
The undiscovered country, at whose sight
The happy smile, and the accursed damned.
But for this, the joyful hope of this,
Who would bear the scorns and flattery of the world,
Scorned by the right rich, the rich cursed of the poor?
The widow being oppressed, the orphan wronged,
The taste of hunger, or a tyrants reign,
And thousand more calamities besides,
To grunt and sweat under this weary life,
When that he may his full Quietus make,
With a bare bodkin, who would this endure,
But for a hope of something after death?
Which puzzles the brain, and doth confound the sense,
Which makes us rather bear those evils we have,
Than fly to others that we know not of.
Aye that, O this conscience makes cowards of us all,
Lady in thy orisons, be all my sins remembered.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: My Lord, I have sought opportunity, which now
I have, to redeliver to your worthy hands, a small remembrance,
such tokens which I have received of you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Are you fair?

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Are you honest?

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: What means my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: That if you be fair and honest,
Your beauty should admit no discourse to your honesty.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: My Lord, can beauty have better privilege than
with honesty?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yea marry may it; for Beauty may transform
Honesty, from what she was into a bawd:
Then Honesty can transform Beauty:
This was sometimes a Paradox,
But now the time gives it scope.
I never gave you nothing.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: My Lord, you know right well you did,
And with them such earnest vows of love,
As would have moved the stoniest breast alive,
But now too true I find,
Rich gifts wax poor, when givers grow unkind.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I never loved you.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: You made me believe you did.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O thou shouldst not have believed me!
Go to a Nunnery go, why shouldst thou
Be a breeder of sinners? I am myself indifferent honest,
But I could accuse myself of such crimes
It had been better my mother had never born me,
O I am very proud, ambitious, disdainful,
With more sins at my beck, than I have thoughts
To put them in, what should such fellows as I
Do, crawling between heaven and earth?
To a Nunnery go, we are arrant knaues all,
Believe none of us, to a Nunnery go.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: O heavens secure him!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Where is thy father?

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: At home my lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: For Gods sake let the doors be shut on him,
He may play the fool nowhere but in his
Own house: to a Nunnery go.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Help him good God.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: If thou dost marry, I will give thee
This plague to thy dowry:
Be thou as chaste as ice, as pure as snow,
Thou shalt not scape calumny, to a Nunnery go.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Alas, what change is this?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: But if thou wilt needs marry, marry a fool,
For wise men know well enough,
What monsters you make of them, to a Nunnery go.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Pray God restore him.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay, I have heard of your paintings too,
God hath given you one face,
And you make yourselves another,
You fig, and you amble, and you nickname Gods creatures,
Making your wantonness, your ignorance,
A pox, it is scurvy, I will no more of it,
It hath made me mad: I will no more marriages,
All that are married but one, shall live,
The rest shall keep as they are, to a Nunnery go,
To a Nunnery go.

sp.speaker: Ofe.
sp.l: Great God of heaven, what a quick change is this?
The Courtier, Scholar, Soldier, all in him,
All dashed and splintered thence, O woe is me,
To have seen what I have seen, see what I see.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Love? No, no, that is not the cause,
Some deeper thing it is that troubles him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Well, something it is: my Lord, content you a while,
I will myself go feel him: let me work,
I will try him every way: see where he comes,
Send you those Gentlemen, let me alone
To find the depth of this, away, be gone.
Now my good Lord, do you know me?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yea very well, you are a fishmonger.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Not I my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Then sir, I would you were so honest a man,
For to be honest, as this age goes,
Is one man to be picked out of ten thousand.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What do you read my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Words, words.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What is the matter my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Between who?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: I mean the matter you read my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Marry most vile heresy:
For here the Satirical Satyr writes,
That old men have hollow eyes, weak backs,
Grey beards, pitiful weak hams, gouty legs,
All which sir, I most patently believe not:
For sir, yourself shall be old as I am,
If like a Crab, you could go backward.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: How pregnant his replies are, and full of wit:
Yet at first he took me for a fishmonger:
All this comes by love, the vehemency of love,
And when I was young, I was very idle,
And suffered much ecstasy in love, very near this:
Will you walk out of the air my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Into my grave.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: By the mass that is out of the air indeed,
Very shrewd answers,
My lord I will take my leave of you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: You can take nothing from me sir,
I will more willingly part with all,
Old doting fool.

sp.speaker: Cor,
sp.l: You seek Prince Hamlet, see, there he is.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: Health to your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What, Gilderstone, and Rossencraft,
Welcome kind School-fellows to Elsanoure.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: We thank your Grace, and would be very glad
You were as when we were at Wittenberg .

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I thank you, but is this visitation free of
Yourselves, or were you not sent for?
Tell me true, come, I know the good King and Queen
Sent for you, there is a kind of confession in your eye:
Come, I know you were sent for.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: What say you?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay then I see how the wind sits,
Come, you were sent for.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: My lord, we were, and willingly if we might,
Know the cause and ground of your discontent.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why I want preferment.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: I think not so my lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yes faith, this great world you see contents me not,
No nor the spangled heavens, nor earth nor sea,
No nor Man that is so glorious a creature,
Contents not me, no nor woman too, though you laugh.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: My lord, we laugh not at that.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why did you laugh then,
When I said, Man did not content me?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: My Lord, we laughed, when you said, Man did not
content you.
What entertainment the Players shall have,
We boarded them a the way: they are coming to you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Players, what Players be they?

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: My Lord, the Tragedians of the City,
Those that you took delight to see so often.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How comes it that they travel? Do they grow restive?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: No my Lord, their reputation holds as it was wont.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How then?

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: Yfaith my Lord, novelty carries it away,
For the principal public audience that
Came to them, are turned to private plays,
And to the humour of children.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I do not greatly wonder of it,
For those that would make mops and moes
At my uncle, when my father lived,
Now give a hundred, two hundred pounds
For his picture: but they shall be welcome,
He that plays the King shall have tribute of me,
The venturous Knight shall use his foil and target,
The lover shall sigh gratis,
The clown shall make them laugh
That are tickled in the lungs, or the blank verse shall halt for it,
And the Lady shall have leave to speak her mind freely.
Do you see yonder great baby?
He is not yet out of his swaddling clouts.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: That may be, for they say an old man
Is twice a child.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will prophecy to you, he comes to tell me of the Players,
You say true, a monday last, it was so indeed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My lord, I have news to tell you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My Lord, I have news to tell you:
When Rossios was an Actor in Rome .

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The Actors are come hither, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Buzz, buzz.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The best Actors in Christendom,
Either for Comedy, Tragedy, History, Pastoral,
Pastoral, Historical, Historical, Comical,
Comical historical, Pastoral, Tragedy historical:
Seneca cannot be too heavy, nor Plato too light:
For the law hath writ those are the only men.

sp.speaker: Ha.
sp.l: O Iepha Judge of Israel ! what a treasure hadst thou?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Why what a treasure had he my lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why one fair daughter, and no more,
The which he loved passing well.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: A, still harping on my daughter! well my Lord,
If you call me Iepha, I have a daughter that
I love passing well.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay that follows not.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: What follows then my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why by lot, or God wot, or as it came to pass,
And so it was, the first verse of the godly Ballet
Will tell you all: for look you where my abridgement comes:
Welcome masters, welcome all,
What my old friend, thy face is valanced
Since I saw thee last, comest thou to beard me in Denmark ?
My young lady and mistress, burlady but your
Ladyship is grown by the altitude of a chopine higher than you were:
Pray God sir your voice, like a piece of uncurrent
Gold, be not cracked in the ring: come on masters,
We will even to it, like French Falconers,
Fly at anything we see, come, a taste of your
Quality, a speech, a passionate speech.

sp.speaker: Players
sp.l: What speech my good lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I heard thee speak a speech once,
But it was never acted: or if it were,
Never above twice, for as I remember,
It pleased not the vulgar, it was caviar
To the million: but to me
And others, that received it in the like kind,
Cried in the top of their judgments, an excellent play,
Set down with as great modesty as cunning:
One said there was no sallets in the lines to make the savoury,
But called it an honest method, as wholesome as sweet.
Come, a speech in it I chiefly remember
Was AEneas tale to Dido,
And then especially where he talks of Princes slaughter,
If it live in thy memory begin at this line,
Let me see.
The rugged Pyrrus, like the arganian beast:
No it is not so, it begins with Pirrus:
O I have it.
The rugged Pirrus, he whose sable arms,
Black as his purpose did the night resemble,
When he lay couched in the ominous horse,
Hath now his black and grim complexion smeared
With Heraldry more dismal, head to foot,
Now is he total guise, horridly tricked
With blood of fathers, mothers, daughters, sons,
Backed and imparched in coagulate gore,
Rifted in earth and fire, old grandsire Pryam seeks:
So go on.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Afore God, my Lord, well spoke, and with good accent.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: A none he finds him striking too short at Greeks,
His antic sword rebellious to his Arm,
Lies where it falls, unable to resist.
Pyrrus at Pryam drives, but all in rage,
Strikes wide, but with the whiff and wind
Of his fell sword, the unnerved father falls.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Enough my friend, it is too long.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It shall to the Barbers with your beard:
A pox, he is for a Jig, or a tale of bawdry,
Or else he sleeps, come on to Hecuba, come.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: But who, O who had seen the mobled Queen?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Mobled Queen is good, faith very good.

sp.speaker: Play.
sp.l: All in the alarum and fear of death rose up,
And over her weak and all ore-teeming loins, a blanket
And a kercher on that head, where late the diadem stood,
Who this had seen with tongue envenomed speech,
Would treason have pronounced,
For if the gods themselves had seen her then,
When she saw Pirrus with malicious strokes,
Mincing her husband's limbs,
It would have made milch the burning eyes of heaven,
And passion in the gods.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Look my lord if he hath not changed his colour,
And hath tears in his eyes: no more good heart, no more.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is well, it is very well, I pray my lord,
Will you see the Players well bestowed,
I tell you they are the Chronicles
And brief abstracts of the time,
After your death I can tell you,
You were better have a bad Epithet,
Than their ill report while you live.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My lord, I will use them according to their deserts.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O far better man, use every man after his deserts,
Then who should scape whipping?
Use them after your own honour and dignity,
The less they deserve, the greater credit is yours.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Welcome my good fellows.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come hither masters, can you not play the murder
of Gonsago?

sp.speaker: players
sp.l: Yes my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And couldst not thou for a need study me
Some dozen or sixteen lines,
Which I would set down and insert?

sp.speaker: players
sp.l: Yes very easily my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is well, I thank you: follow that lord:
And do you hear sirs? take heed you mock him not.
Gentlemen, for your kindness I thank you,
And for a time I would desire you leave me.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: Our love and duty is at your command.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why what a dunghill idiot slave am I?
Why these Players here draw water from eyes:
For Hecuba, why what is Hecuba to him, or he to Hecuba?
What would he do and if he had my loss?
His father murdered, and a Crown bereft him,
He would turn all his tears to drops of blood,
Amaze the standers by with his laments,
Strike more than wonder in the judicial ears,
Confound the ignorant, and make mute the wise,
Indeed his passion would be general.
Yet I like to an ass and Iohn a Dreams,
Having my father murdered by a villain,
Stand still, and let it pass, why sure I am a coward:
Who plucks me by the beard, or twits my nose,
Gives me the lie in the throat down to the lungs,
Sure I should take it, or else I have no gall,
Or by this I should have fatted all the region kites
With this slave's offal, this damned villain,
Treacherous, bawdy, murderous villain:
Why this is brave, that I the son of my dear father,
Should like a scallion, like a very drab
Thus rail in words. About my brain,
I have heard that guilty creatures sitting at a play,
Hath, by the very cunning of the scene, confessed a murder
Committed long before.
This spirit that I have seen may be the Devil,
And out of my weakness and my melancholy,
As he is very potent with such men,
Doth seek to damn me, I will have sounder proofs,
The play is the thing,
Wherein I will catch the conscience of the King.

div1.stage: Enter the King, Queene, and Lordes.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Lords, can you by no means find
The cause of our son Hamlets lunacy?
You being so near in love, even from his youth,
Methinks should gain more than a stranger should.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: My lord, we have done all the best we could,
To wring from him the cause of all his grief,
But still he puts us off, and by no means
Would make an answer to that we exposed.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: Yet was he something more inclined to mirth
Before we left him, and I take it,
He hath given order for a play tonight,
At which he craves your highness company.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: With all our heart, it likes us very well:
Gentlemen, seek still to increase his mirth,
Spare for no cost, our coffers shall be open,
And we unto yourselves will still be thankful.

sp.speaker: Both
sp.l: In all we can, be sure you shall command.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Thanks gentlemen, and what the Queen of Denmark
May pleasure you, be sure you shall not want.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: We will once again unto the noble Prince.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Thanks to you both: Gertred you will see this play.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: My lord I will, and it joys me at the soul
He is inclined to any kind of mirth.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam, I pray be ruled by me:
And my good Sovereign, give me leave to speak,
We cannot yet find out the very ground
Of his distemperance, therefore
I hold it meet, if so it please you,
Else they shall not meet, and thus it is.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What is it Corambis ?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Marry my good lord this, soon when the sports are done,
Madam, send you in haste to speak with him,
And I myself will stand behind the Arras,
There question you the cause of all his grief,
And then in love and nature unto you, he will tell you all:
My Lord, how think you on it?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: It likes us well, Gerterd, what say you?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: With all my heart, soon will I send for him.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Myself will be that happy messenger,
Who hopes his grief will be revealed to her.

div1.stage:
exeunt omnes
Enter Hamlet and the Players.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Pronounce me this speech trippingly on the tongue
as I taught thee,
Marry and you mouth it, as a many of your players do
I would rather hear a town bull bellow,
Than such a fellow speak my lines.
Nor do not saw the air thus with your hands,
But give everything his action with temperance.
O it offends me to the soul, to hear a robustious periwig fellow,
To tear a passion in totters, into very rags,
To split the ears of the ignorant, who for the
Most part are capable of nothing but dumb shows and noises,
I would have such a fellow whipped, for over doing, termagant
It out, Herodes Herod.

sp.speaker: players
sp.l: My Lord, we have indifferently reformed that
among us.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The better, the better, mend it all together:
There be fellows that I have seen play,
And heard others commend them, and that highly too,
That having neither the gate of Christian, Pagan,
Nor Turk, have so strutted and bellowed,
That you would have thought, some of Natures journeymen
Had made men, and not made them well,
They imitated humanity, so abominable:
Take heed, avoid it.

sp.speaker: players
sp.l: I warrant you my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And do you hear? let not your Clown speak
More than is set down, there be of them I can tell you
That will laugh themselves, to set on some
Quantity of barren spectators to laugh with them,
Albeit there is some necessary point in the Play
Then to be observed: O it is vile, and shows
A pitiful ambition in the fool that useth it.
And then you have some again, that keeps one suit
Of jests, as a man is known by one suit of
Apparel, and Gentlemen quotes his jests down
In their tables, before they come to the play, as thus:
Cannot you stay till I eat my porridge? and, you owe me
A quarters wages: and, my coat wants a cullison:
And, your beer is sour: and, blabbering with his lips,
And thus keeping in his cinquapace of jests,
When, God knows, the warm Clown cannot make a jest
Unless by chance, as the blind man catcheth a hare:
Masters tell him of it.

sp.speaker: players
sp.l: We will my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Well, go make you ready.

sp.speaker: Horatio.
sp.l: Here my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Horatio, thou art even as just a man,
As ever my conversation coped withal.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: O my lord!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay why should I flatter thee?
Why should the poor be flattered?
What gain should I receive by flattering thee,
That nothing hath but thy good mind?
Let flattery sit on those time-pleasing tongs,
To gloze with them that loves to hear their praise,
And not with such as thou Horatio .
There is a play tonight, wherein one Scene they have
Comes very near the murder of my father,
When thou shalt see that Act afoot,
Mark thou the King, do but observe his looks,
For I mine eyes will rivet to his face:
And if he do not bleach, and change at that,
It is a damned ghost that we have seen.
Horatio, have a care, observe him well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My lord, mine eyes shall still be on his face,
And not the smallest alteration
That shall appear in him, but I shall note it.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hark, they come.

div1.stage: Enter King, Queene, Corambis, and other Lords.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: How now son Hamlet, how fare you, shall we have a play?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Yfaith the Chameleon's dish, not capon crammed,
feed a the air.
Aye father: My lord, you played in the University.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: That I did my Lord: and I was counted a good actor.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What did you enact there?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My lord, I did act Julius Caesar, I was killed
in the Capitol, Brutus killed me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It was a brute part of him,
To kill so capital a calf.
Come, be these Players ready?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Hamlet come sit down by me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No by my faith mother, here is a mettle more attractive:
Lady will you give me leave, and so forth:
To lay my head in your lap?

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: No my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Upon your lap, what do you think I meant contrary matters?

div1.stage: Enter in a Dumbe Shew, the King and the Queene, he sits downe in an Arbor, she leaues him: Then enters Lucianus with poyson in a Viall, and powres it in his eares, and goes away: Then the Queene commeth and findes him dead: and goes away with the other.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: What means this my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: This is mitching Mallico, that means my chief.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: What doth this mean my lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: you shall hear anon, this fellow will tell you all.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Will he tell us what this show means?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye, or any show you will show him,
Be not afeared to show, he will not be afeared to tell:
O these Players cannot keep counsel, they will tell all.

sp.speaker: Prol.
sp.l: For us, and for our Tragedy,
Here stooping to your clemency,
We beg your hearing patiently.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Is it a prologue, or a posy for a ring?

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: It is short my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: As women's love.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Full forty years are past, their date is gone,
Since happy time joined both our hearts as one:
And now the blood that filled my youthful veins,
Runs weakly in their pipes, and all the strains
Of music, which whilom pleased mine ear,
Is now a burthen that Age cannot bear:
And therefore sweet Nature must pay his due,
To heaven must I, and leave the earth with you.

sp.speaker: Dutchesse
sp.l: O say not so, lest that you kill my heart,
When death takes you, let life from me depart.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Content thyself, when ended is my date,
Thou mayst (perchance) have a more noble mate,
More wise, more youthful, and one.

sp.speaker: Dutchesse
sp.l: O speak no more, for then I am accursed,
None weds the second, but she kills the first:
A second time I kill my Lord that is dead,
When second husband kisses me in bed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O wormwood, wormwood!

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I do believe you sweet, what now you speak,
But what we do determine oft we break,
For our demises still are overthrown,
Our thoughts are ours, their end is none of our own:
So think you will no second husband wed,
But die thy thoughts, when thy first Lord is dead.

sp.speaker: Dutchesse
sp.l: Both here and there pursue me lasting strife,
If once a widow, ever I be wife.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: If she should break now.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: It is deeply sworn, sweet leave me here a while,
My spirits grow dull, and fain I would beguile the tedious
time with sleep.

sp.speaker: Dutchesse
sp.l: Sleep rock thy brain,
And never come mischance between us twain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Madam, how do you like this play?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: The Lady protests too much.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O but she will keep her word.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Have you heard the argument, is there no offence
in it?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No offence in the world, poison in jest, poison in jest.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What do you call the name of the play?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Mouse-trap: marry how tropically: this play is
The image of a murder done in guyana, Albertus
Was the Dukes name, his wife Baptista,
Father, it is a knavish piece a work: but what
Of that, it toucheth not us, you and I that have free
Souls, let the galled jade wince, this is one
Lucianus nephew to the King.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: You are as good as a Chorus my lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I could interpret the love you bear, if I saw the
puppets dallying.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: You are very pleasant my lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Who I, your only jig-maker, why what should
a man do but be merry? for look how cheerfully my mother
looks, my father died within these two hours.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Nay, it is twice two months, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Two months, nay then let the devil wear black,
For I will have a suit of Sables: Jesus, two months dead,
And not forgotten yet? nay then there is some
Likelihood, a gentleman's death may outlive memory,
But by my faith he must build churches then,
Or else he must follow the old Epithet,
With ho, with ho, the hobbyhorse is forgot.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Your jests are keen my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It would cost you a groaning to take them off.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Still better and worse.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: So you must take your husband, begin. Murdered
Begin, a pox, leave thy damnable faces and begin,
Come, the croaking raven doth bellow for revenge.

sp.speaker: Murd.
sp.l: Thoughts black, hands apt, drugs fit, and time agreeing.
Confederate season, else no creature seeing:
Thou mixture rank, of midnight weeds collected,
With Hecates bane thrice blasted, thrice infected,
Thy natural magic, and dire property,
One wholesome life usurps immediately.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: He poisons him for his estate.

sp.speaker: ing
sp.l: Lights, I will to bed.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: The king rises, lights ho.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What, frighted with false fires?
Then let the stricken deer go weep,
The Hart ungalled play,
For some must laugh, while some must weep,
Thus runs the world away.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: The king is moved my lord.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye Horatio, I will take the Ghosts word
For more than all the coin in Denmark .

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: Now my lord, how is it with you?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And if the king like not the tragedy,
Why then belike he likes it not perdy.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: We are very glad to see your grace so pleasant,
My good lord, let us again entreat
To know of you the ground and cause of your distemperature

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: My lord, your mother craves to speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: We shall obey, were she ten times our mother.

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: But my good Lord, shall I entreat thus much?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I pray will you play upon this pipe?

sp.speaker: Ross.
sp.l: Alas my lord I cannot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Pray will you.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: I have no skill my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: why look, it is a thing of nothing,
It is but stopping of these holes,
And with a little breath from your lips,
It will give most delicate music.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: But this cannot we do my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Pray now, pray heartily, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: My lord we cannot.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why how unworthy a thing would you make of me?
You would seem to know my stops, you would play upon me,
You would search the very inward part of my heart,
And dive into the secret of my soul.
Zownds do you think I am easier to be played
On, than a pipe? call me what Instrument
You will, though you can fret me, yet you cannot
Play upon me, besides, to be demanded by a sponge.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: How a sponge my Lord?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye sir, a sponge, that soaks up the kings
Countenance, favours, and rewards, that makes
His liberality your store house: but such as you,
Do the king, in the end, best service;
For he doth keep you as an Ape doth nuts,
In the corner of his Jaw, first mouths you,
Then swallows you: so when he hath need
Of you, it is but squeezing of you,
And sponge, you shall be dry again, you shall.

sp.speaker: Ros.
sp.l: Well my Lord we will take our leave.

sp.speaker: Ham
sp.l: Farewell, farewell, God bless you.

div1.stage:
Exit Rossencraft and Gilderstone.
Enter Corambis

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: My lord, the Queen would speak with you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Do you see yonder cloud in the shape of a camel?

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It is like a camel in deed.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Now methinks it is like a weasel.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: It is backed like a weasel.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Or like a whale.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Very like a whale.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why then tell my mother I will come by and by.
Good night Horatio.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Good night unto your Lordship.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My mother she hath sent to speak with me:
O God, let never the heart of Nero enter
This soft bosom.
Let me be cruel, not unnatural.
I will speak daggers, those sharpe words being spent,
To do her wrong my soul shall never consent.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: O that this wet that falls upon my face
Would wash the crime clear from my conscience!
When I look up to heaven, I see my trespass,
The earth doth still cry out upon my fact,
Pay me the murder of a brother and a king,
And the adulterous fault I have committed:
O these are sins that are unpardonable:
Why say thy sins were blacker than is jet,
Yet may contrition make them as white as snow:
I but still to persevere in a sin,
It is an act against the universal power,
Most wretched man, stoop, bend thee to thy prayer,
Ask grace of heaven to keep thee from despair.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye so, come forth and work thy last,
And thus he dies: and so am I revenged:
No, not so: he took my father sleeping, his sins brim full,
And how his soul stood to the state of heaven
Who knows, save the immortal powers,
And shall I kill him now,
When he is purging of his soul?
Making his way for heaven, this is a benefit,
And not revenge: no, get thee up again,
When he is at game swearing, taking his carouse, drinking drunk,
Or in the incestuous pleasure of his bed,
Or at some act that hath no relish
Of salvation in it, then trip him
That his heels may kick at heaven,
And fall as low as hell: my mother stays,
This physic but prolongs thy weary days.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: My words fly up, my sins remain below.
No King on earth is safe, if Gods his foe.

div1.stage:
exit King.
Enter Queene and Corambis.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Madam, I hear young Hamlet coming,
I will shroud myself behind the Arras.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Do so my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Mother, mother, O are you here?
How is it with you mother?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: How is it with you?

sp.speaker: Ham,
sp.l: I will tell you, but first we will make all safe.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Hamlet, thou hast thy father much offended.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Mother, you have my father much offended.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: How now boy?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How now mother! come here, sit down, for you
shall hear me speak.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: What wilt thou do? thou wilt not murder me:
Help ho.

sp.speaker: Cor.
sp.l: Help for the Queen.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye a Rat, dead for a Ducat.
Rash intruding fool, farewell,
I took thee for thy better.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Hamlet, what hast thou done?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Not so much harm, good mother,
As to kill a king, and marry with his brother.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: How! kill a king!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye a King: nay sit you down, and ere you part,
If you be made of penetrable stuff,
I will make your eyes look down into your heart,
And see how horrid there and black it shows.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Hamlet, what meanest thou by these killing words?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why this I mean, see here, behold this picture,
It is the portraiture, of your deceased husband,
See here a face, to outface Mars himself,
An eye, at which his foes did tremble at,
A front wherein all virtues are set down
For to adorn a king, and guild his crown,
Whose heart went hand in hand even with that vow,
He made to you in marriage, and he is dead.
Murdered, damnably murdered, this was your husband,
Look you now, here is your husband,
With a face like Vulcan.
A look fit for a murder and a rape,
A dull dead hanging look, and a hell-bred eye,
To affright children and amaze the world:
And this same have you left to change with this.
What Devil thus hath cozened you at hob-man blind?
A! have you eyes and can you look on him
That slew my father, and your dear husband,
To live in the incestuous pleasure of his bed?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O Hamlet, speak no more.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: To leave him that bare a Monarch's mind,
For a king of clouts, of very shreds.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Sweet Hamlet cease.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay but still to persist and dwell in sin,
To sweat under the yoke of infamy,
To make increase of shame, to seal damnation.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Hamlet, no more.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why appetite with you is in the wain,
Your blood runs backward now from whence it came,
who will chide hot blood within a Virgins heart,
When lust shall dwell within a matrons breast?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Hamlet, thou cleaves my heart in twain.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O throw away the worser part of it, and keep the
better.

div1.stage: Enter the ghost in his night gowne.

sp.l: Save me, save me, you gracious
Powers above, and hover over me,
With your celestial wings.
do you not come your tardy son to chide,
That I thus long have let revenge slip by?
O do not glare with looks so pitiful!
Lest that my heart of stone yield to compassion,
And every part that should assist revenge,
Forgo their proper powers, and fall to pity.

sp.speaker: Ghost
sp.l: Hamlet, I once again appear to thee,
To put thee in remembrance of my death:
Do not neglect, nor long time put it off.
But I perceive by thy distracted looks,
Thy mother is fearful, and she stands amazed:
Speak to her Hamlet, for her sex is weak,
Comfort thy mother, Hamlet, think on me.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: How is it with you Lady?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Nay, how is it with you
That thus you bend your eyes on vacancy,
And hold discourse with nothing but with air?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why do you nothing hear?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nor do you nothing see?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: No neither.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No, why see the king my father, my father, in the habit
As he lived, look you how pale he looks,
See how he steals away out of the Portal,
Look, there he goes.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Alas, it is the weakness of thy brain,
Which makes thy tongue to blazon thy hearts grief:
But as I have a soul, I swear by heaven,
I never knew of this most horrid murder:
But Hamlet, this is only fantasy,
And for my love forget these idle fits.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Idle, no mother, my pulse doth beat like yours,
It is not madness that possesseth Hamlet.
O mother, if ever you did my dear father love,
Forbear the adulterous bed tonight,
And win yourself by little as you may,
In time it may be you will loathe him quite:
And mother, but assist me in revenge,
And in his death your infamy shall die.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Hamlet, I vow by that majesty,
That knows our thoughts, and looks into our hearts,
I will conceal, consent, and do my best,
What stratagem soever thou shalt devise.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is enough, mother good night:
Come sir, I will provide for you a grave,
Who was in life a foolish prating knave.

div1.stage: Exit Hamlet with the dead body.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now Gertred, what says our son, how do you
find him?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Alas my lord, as raging as the sea:
Whenas he came, I first bespake him fair,
But then he throws and tosses me about,
As one forgetting that I was his mother:
At last I called for help: and as I cried, Corambis
Called, which Hamlet no sooner heard, but whips me
Out his rapier, and cries, a Rat, a Rat, and in his rage
The good old man he kills.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Why this his madness will undo our state.
Lords go to him, inquire the body out.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: We will my Lord.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Gertred, your son shall presently to England,
His shipping is already furnished,
And we have sent by Rossencraft and Gilderstone,
our letters to our dear brother of England,
For Hamlets welfare and his happiness:
Happily the air and climate of the Country
May please him better than his native home:
See where he comes.

sp.speaker: Gil.
sp.l: My lord, we can by no means
Know of him where the body is.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now son Hamlet, where is this dead body?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: At supper, not where he is eating, but
Where he is eaten, a certain company of politic worms are even now at him.
Father, your fat King, and your lean Beggar
Are but variable services, two dishes to one mess:
Look you, a man may fish with that worm
That hath eaten of a King,
And a Beggar eat that fish,
Which that worm hath caught.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: What of this?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nothing father, but to tell you, how a King
May go a progress through the guts of a Beggar.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: But son Hamlet, where is this body?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: In heaven, if you chance to miss him there,
Father, you had best look in the other parts below
For him, and if you cannot find him there,
You may chance to nose him as you go up the lobby.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Make haste and find him out.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Nay do you hear? do not make too much haste,
I will warrant you he will stay till you come.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Well son Hamlet, we in care of you: but specially
in tender preservation of your health,
The which we price even as our proper self,
It is our mind you forthwith go for England,
The wind sits fair, you shall aboard tonight,
Lord Rossencraft and Gilderstone shall go along with you.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O with all my heart: farewell mother.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Your loving father, Hamlet .

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: My mother I say: you married my mother,
My mother is your wife, man and wife is one flesh,
And so (my mother) farewell: for England ho.

sp.speaker: king
sp.l: Gertred, leave me,
And take your leave of Hamlet,
To England is he gone, never to return:
Our Letters are unto the King of England,
That on the sight of them, on his allegiance,
He presently without demanding why,
That Hamlet lose his head, for he must die,
There is more in him than shallow eyes can see:
He once being dead, why then our state is free.

div1.stage:
exit.
Enter Fortenbrasse, Drumme and Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Captain, from us go greet
The king of Denmark:
Tell him that Fortenbrasse nephew to old Norway,
Craves a free pass and conduct over his land,
According to the Articles agreed on:
You know our Rendezvous, go march away.

div1.stage:
exeunt all.
enter King and Queene.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Hamlet is shipped for England, fare him well,
I hope to hear good news from thence ere long,
If everything fall out to our content,
As I do make no doubt but so it shall.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: God grant it may, heavens keep my Hamlet safe:
But this mischance of old Corambis death,
Hath pierced so the young Ofeliaes heart,
That she, poor maid, is quite bereft her wits.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Alas dear heart! And on the other side,
We understand her brother has come from France,
And he hath half the heart of all our Land,
And hardly he will forget his fathers death,
Unless by some means he be pacified.

sp.speaker: Qu.
sp.l: O see where the young Ofelia is!

div1.stage: Enter Ofelia playing on a Lute, and her haire downe singing.

sp.speaker: Ofelia
sp.l: How should I your true love know
From another man?
By his cockle hat, and his staff,
And his sandal shoon.
White his shroud as mountain snow,
Larded with sweet flowers,
That bewept to the grave did not go
With true lover's showers:
He is dead and gone Lady, he is dead and gone,
At his head a grass green turf,
At his heels a stone.

sp.speaker: king
sp.l: How is it with you sweet Ofelia ?

sp.speaker: Ofelia
sp.l: Well God yield you,
It grieves me to see how they laid him in the cold ground,
I could not choose but weep:
And will he not come again?
And will he not come again?
No, no, he is gone, and we cast away moan,
And he never will come again.
His beard as white as snow:
All flaxen was his pole,
He is dead, he is gone,
And we cast away moan:
God have mercy on his soul.
And of all christen souls I pray God.
God be with you Ladies, God be with you.

sp.speaker: king [
sp.l: A pretty wretch! this is a change indeed:
O Time, how swiftly runs our joys away?
Content on earth was never certain bred,
Today we laugh and live, tomorrow dead.
How now, what noise is that?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Stay there until I come,
O thou vild king, give me my father:
Speak, say, where is my father?

sp.speaker: king
sp.l: Dead.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Who hath murdered him? speak, I will not
Be juggled with, for he is murdered.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: True, but not by him.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: By whom, by heaven I will be resolved.

sp.speaker: king
