sp.l: Let him go Gertred, away, I fear him not,
There is such divinity doth wall a king,
That treason dares not look on.
Let him go Gertred, that your father is murdered,
It is true, and we most sorry for it,
Being the chiefest pillar of our state:
Therefore will you like a most desperate gamester,
Swoop-stake-like, draw at friend, and foe, and all?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: To his good friends thus wide I will ope mine arms,
And lock them in my heart, but to his foes,
I will no reconcilement but by blood.

sp.speaker: king [
sp.l: Why now you speak like a most loving son:
And that in soul we sorrow for for his death,
Yourself ere long shall be a witness,
Mean while be patient, and content yourself.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Who is this, Ofelia ? O my dear sister!
Is it possible a young maid's life,
Should be as mortal as an old man's saw?
O heavens themselves! how now Ofelia ?

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Well God a mercy, I have been gathering of flowers:
Here, here is rue for you,
You may call it herb a grace a Sundays,
Here is some for me too: you must wear your rue
With a difference, there is a daisy.
Here Love, there is rosemary for you
For remembrance: I pray Love remember,
And there is pansy for thoughts.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: A document in madness, thoughts, remembrance:
O God, O God!

sp.speaker: Ofelia
sp.l: There is fennel for you, I would have given you
Some violets, but they all withered, when
My father died: alas, they say the owl was
A Bakers daughter, we see what we are,
But cannot tell what we shall be.
For bonny sweet Robin is all my joy.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Thoughts and afflictions, torments worse than hell.

sp.speaker: Ofel.
sp.l: Nay Love, I pray you make no words of this now:
I pray now, you shall sing a down,
And you a down a, it is of the Kings daughter
And the false steward, and if anybody
Ask you of anything, say you this.
Tomorrow is saint Valentines day,
All in the morning betime,
And a maid at your window,
To be your Valentine:
The young man rose, and donned his clothes,
And dupped the chamber door,
Let in the maid, that out a maid
Never departed more.
Nay I pray mark now,
By gis, and by saint Charity,
Away, and fie for shame:
Young men will do it when they come to it:
By cock they are to blame.
Quoth she, before you tumbled me,
You promised me to wed.
So would I have done, by yonder Sun,
If thou hadst not come to my bed.
So God be with you all, God bwy Ladies.
God bwy you Love.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Grief upon grief, my father murdered,
My sister thus distracted:
Cursed be his soul that wrought this wicked act.

sp.speaker: king
sp.l: Content you good Leartes for a time,
Although I know your grief is as a flood,
Brim full of sorrow, but forbear a while,
And think already the revenge is done
On him that makes you such a hapless son.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: You have prevailed my Lord, a while I will strive,
To bury grief within a tomb of wrath,
Which once unhorsed, then the world shall hear
Leartes had a father he held dear.

sp.speaker: king
sp.l: No more of that, ere many days be done,
You shall hear that you do not dream upon.

div1.stage:
exeunt om.
Enter Horatio and the Queene.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Madam, your son is safe arrived in Denmark,
This letter I even now received of him,
Whereas he writes how he escaped the danger,
And subtle treason that the king had plotted,
Being crossed by the contention of the winds,
He found the Packet sent to the king of England,
Wherein he saw himself betrayed to death,
As at his next conversion with your grace,
He will relate the circumstance at full.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Then I perceive there is treason in his looks
That seemed to sugar over his villainy:
But I will soothe and please him for a time,
For murderous minds are always jealous,
But know not you Horatio where he is?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Yes Madam, and he hath appointed me
To meet him on the east side of the City
Tomorrow morning.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O fail not, good Horatio, and withal, commend me
A mothers care to him, bid him a while
Be wary of his presence, lest that he
Fail in that he goes about.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Madam, never make doubt of that:
I think by this the news be come to court:
He is arrived, observe the king, and you shall
Quickly find, Hamlet being here,
Things fell not to his mind.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: But what became of Gilderstone and Rossencraft ?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He being set ashore, they went for England,
And in the Packet there writ down that doom
To be performed on them pointed for him:
And by great chance he had his fathers Seal,
So all was done without discovery.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Thanks be to heaven for blessing of the prince,
Horatio once again I take my leave,
With thousand mothers blessings to my son.

sp.speaker: Horat.
sp.l: Madam adieu.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Hamlet from England ! is it possible?
What chance is this? they are gone, and he come home.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O he is welcome, by my soul he is:
At it my jocund heart doth leap for joy,
That I shall live to tell him, thus he dies.

sp.speaker: king
sp.l: Leartes, content yourself, be ruled by me,
And you shall have no let for your revenge.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: My will, not all the world.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Nay but Leartes, mark the plot I have laid,
I have heard him often with a greedy wish,
Upon some praise that he hath heard of you
Touching your weapon, which with all his heart,
He might be once tasked for to try your cunning.

sp.speaker: Lea.
sp.l: And how for this?

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Marry Leartes thus: I will lay a wager,
Shall be on Hamlets side, and you shall give the odds,
The which will draw him with a more desire,
To try the mastery, that in twelve venues
You gain not three of him: now this being granted,
When you are hot in midst of all your play,
Among the foils shall a keen rapier lie,
Steeped in a mixture of deadly poison,
That if it draws but the least dram of blood,
In any part of him, he cannot live:
This being done will free you from suspicion,
And not the dearest friend that Hamlet loved
Will ever have Leartes in suspect.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: My lord, I like it well:
But say lord Hamlet should refuse this match.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: I will warrant you, we will put on you
Such a report of singularity,
Will bring him on, although against his will.
And lest that all should miss,
I will have a potion that shall ready stand,
In all his heat when that he calls for drink,
Shall be his period and our happiness.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: It is excellent, O would the time were come!
Here comes the Queen.

sp.speaker: king
sp.l: How now Gertred, why look you heavily?

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O my Lord, the young Ofelia
Having made a garland of sundry sorts of flowers,
Sitting upon a willow by a brooke,
The envious sprig broke, into the brooke she fell,
And for a while her clothes spread wide abroad,
Bore the young Lady up: and there she sate smiling,
Even Mermaid-like, betwixt heaven and earth,
Chanting old sundry tunes uncapable
As it were of her distress, but long it could not be,
Till that her clothes, being heavy with their drink,
Dragged the sweet wretch to death.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: So, she is drowned:
Too much of water hast thou Ofelia,
Therefore I will not drown thee in my tears,
Revenge it is must yield this heart relief,
For woe begets woe, and grief hangs on grief.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: I say no, she ought not to be buried
In christian burial.
Why sir?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Marry because she is drowned.
But she did not drown herself.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: No, that is certain, the water drowned her.
Yea but it was against her will.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: No, I deny that, for look you sir, I stand here,
If the water come to me, I drown not myself:
But if I go to the water, and am there drowned,
Ergo I am guilty of my own death:
You are gone, go you are gone sir.
Aye but see, she hath christian burial,
Because she is a great woman.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Marry more is the pity, that great folk
Should have more authority to hang or drown
Themselves, more than other people:
Go fetch me a stoup of drink, but before thou
Goest, tell me one thing, who builds strongest,
Of a Mason, a Shipwright, or a Carpenter?
Why a Mason, for he builds all of stone,
And will endure long.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: That is pretty, to it again, to it again.
Why then a Carpenter, for he builds the gallows,
And that brings many a one to his long home.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Pretty again, the gallows doth well, marry howe
does it well? the gallows does well to them that do ill,
go get thee gone:
And if anyone ask thee hereafter, say,
A Grave-maker, for the houses he builds
Last till Doomsday. Fetch me a stoup of beer, go.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: A pick-axe and a spade,
A spade for and a winding sheet,
Most fit it is, for it will be made,
For such a guest most meet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Hath this fellow any feeling of himself,
That is thus merry in making of a grave?
See how the slave joles their heads against the earth.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My lord, Custom hath made it in him seem nothing.

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: A pick-axe and a spade, a spade,
For and a winding sheet,
Most fit it is for to be made,
For such a guest most meet.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Look you, there is another Horatio .
Why may it not be the scull of some Lawyer?
Methinks he should indict that fellow
Of an action of Battery, for knocking
Him about the pate with his shovel: now where is your
Quirks and quillets now, your vouchers and
Double vouchers, your leases and free-hold,
And tenements? why that same box there will scarce
Hold the conveyance of his land, and must
The honour lie there? O pitiful transformance!
I prithee tell me Horatio,
Is parchment made of sheep-skins?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye my Lord, and of calves' skins too.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: In faith they prove themselves sheep and calves
That deal with them, or put their trust in them.
There is another, why may not that be such a ones
Scull, that praised my Lord such a ones horse,
When he meant to beg him? Horatio, I prithee
Let us question yonder fellow.
Now my friend, whose grave is this?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Mine sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: But who must lie in it?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: If I should say, I should, I should lie in my throat sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What man must be buried here?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: No man sir.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What woman?

sp.speaker: Clowne.
sp.l: No woman neither sir, but indeed
One that was a woman.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: An excellent fellow by the Lord Horatio,
This seven years have I noted it: the toe of the peasant,
Comes so near the heel of the courtier,
That he galls his kibe, I prithee tell me one thing,
How long will a man lie in the ground before he rots?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: In faith sir, if he be not rotten before
He be laid in, as we have many pocky corses,
He will last you, eight years, a tanner
Will last you eight years full out, or nine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And why a tanner?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Why his hide is so tanned with his trade,
That it will hold out water, that is a parlous
Devourer of your dead body, a great soaker.
Look you, here is a scull hath been here this dozen year,
Let me see, I ever since our last king Hamlet
Slew Fortenbrasse in combat, young Hamlets father,
He that is mad.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Aye marry, how came he mad?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: In faith very strangely, by loosing of his wits.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Upon what ground?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: On this ground, in Denmark.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Where is he now?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Why now they sent him to England .

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: To England ! wherefore?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Why they say he shall have his wits there,
Or if he have not, it is no great matter there,
It will not be seen there.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Why not there?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: Why there they say the men are as mad as he.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Whose scull was this?

sp.speaker: Clowne
sp.l: This, a plague on him, a mad rogues it was,
He poured once a whole flagon of Rhenish of my head,
Why do not you know him? this was one Yorickes scull.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Was this? I prithee let me see it, alas poor Yoricke
I knew him Horatio,
A fellow of infinite mirth, he hath carried me twenty times
upon his back, here hung those lips that I have Kissed a
hundred times, and to see, now they abhor me: Where is
your jests now Yoricke? your flashes of merriment: now go
to my Ladies chamber, and bid her paint herself an inch
thick, to this she must come Yoricke. Horatio, I prithee
tell me one thing, dost thou think that Alexander looked
thus?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Even so my Lord.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And smelt thus?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Aye my lord, no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No, why might not imagination work, as thus of
Alexander, Alexander died, Alexander was buried, Alexander
became earth, of earth we make clay, and Alexander being
but clay, why might not time bring to pass, that he might
stop the bung hole of a beer barrel?
Imperious Caesar dead and turned to clay,
Might stop a hole, to keep the wind away.

div1.stage: Enter King and Queene, Leartes, and other lordes, with a Priest after the coffin.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What funeral is this that all the Court laments?
It shows to be some noble parentage:
Stand by a while.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: What ceremony else? say, what ceremony else?

sp.speaker: Priest
sp.l: My Lord, we have done all that lies in us,
And more than well the church can tolerate,
She hath had a Dirge sung for her maiden soul:
And but for favour of the king, and you,
She had been buried in the open fields,
Where now she is allowed christian burial.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: So, I tell thee churlish Priest, a ministering Angel
shall my sister be, when thou liest howling.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The fair Ofelia dead!

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Sweets to the sweet, farewell:
I had thought to adorn thy bridal bed, fair maid,
And not to follow thee unto thy grave.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Forbear the earth a while: sister farewell:
Now power your earth on, Olympus hie,
And make a hill to over top old Pellon :
Whats he that conjures so?

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Behold it is I, Hamlet the Dane.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: The devil take thy soul.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: O thou prayest not well,
I prithee take thy hand from off my throat,
For there is something in me dangerous,
Which let thy wisdom fear, hold off thy hand:
I loved Ofelia as dear as twenty brothers could:
Show me what thou wilt do for her:
Wilt fight, wilt fast, wilt pray,
Wilt drink up vessels, eat a crocodile? I will do it:
Comest thou here to whine?
And where thou talkest of burying thee alive,
Here let us stand: and let them throw on us,
Whole hills of earth, till with the heighth thereof,
Make Oosell as a Wart.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Forbear Leartes, now is he mad, as is the sea,
Anon as mild and gentle as a Dove:
Therefore a while give his wild humour scope.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: What is the reason sir that you wrong me thus?
I never gave you cause: but stand away,
A Cat will meow, a Dog will have a day.

sp.speaker: Queene.
sp.l: Alas, it is his madness makes him thus,
And not his heart, Leartes .

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: My lord, it is so: but we will no longer trifle,
This very day shall Hamlet drink his last,
For presently we mean to send to him,
Therefore Leartes be in readiness.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: My lord, till then my soul will not be quiet.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.l: Come Gertred, we will have Leartes, and our son,
Made friends and Lovers, as befits them both,
Even as they tender us, and love their country.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: God grant they may.

div1.stage:
exeunt omnes.
Enter Hamlet and Horatio

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: believe me, it grieves me much Horatio,
That to Leartes I forgot myself:
For by myself methinks I feel his grief,
Though there is a difference in each others wrong.

sp.speaker: Horatio,
sp.l: but mark yon water-fly,
The Court knows him, but he knows not the Court.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Now God save thee, sweet prince Hamlet .

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And you sir: foh, how the musk-cod smells!

sp.speaker: Gen.
sp.l: I come with an embassage from his majesty to you

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I shall sir give you attention:
By my troth methinks it is very cold.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: It is indeed very rawish cold.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: It is hot methinks.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Very sweltery hot:
The King, sweet Prince, hath laid a wager on your side,
Six Barbary horse, against six french rapiers,
With all their accoutrements too, on the carriages:
In good faith they are very curiously wrought.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The carriages sir, I do not know what you mean.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: The girdles, and hangers sir, and such like.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The word had been more cousin german to the
phrase, if he could have carried the canon by his side,
And how is the wager? I understand you now.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: Marry sir, that young Leartes in twelve venues
At Rapier and Dagger do not get three odds of you,
And on your side the King hath laid,
And desires you to be in readiness.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Very well, if the King dare venture his wager,
I dare venture my skull: when must this be?

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: My Lord, presently, the king, and her majesty,
With the rest of the best judgment in the Court,
Are coming down into the outward palace.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Go tell his majesty, I will attend him.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: I shall deliver your most sweet answer.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: You may sir, none better, for you are spiced,
Else he had a bad nose could not smell a fool.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: He will disclose himself without inquiry.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Believe me Horatio, my heart is on the sudden
Very sore, all here about.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: My lord, forbear the challenge then.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: No Horatio, not I, if danger be now,
Why then it is not to come, there is a predestinate providence
in the fall of a sparrow: here comes the King.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Now son Hamlet, we have laid upon your head,
And make no question but to have the best.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Your majesty hath laid a the weaker side.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: We doubt it not, deliver them the foils.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: First Leartes, here is my hand and love,
Protesting that I never wronged Leartes.
If Hamlet in his madness did amiss,
That was not Hamlet, but his madness did it,
And all the wrong I ever did to Leartes,
I here proclaim was madness, therefore let us be at peace,
And think I have shot mine arrow over the house,
And hurt my brother.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Sir I am satisfied in nature,
But in terms of honour I will stand aloof,
And will no reconcilement,
Till by some elder masters of our time
I may be satisfied.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Give them the foils.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: I will be your foil Leartes, these foils,
Have all a laughed, come on sir:

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: No none.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Judgment.

sp.speaker: Gent.
sp.l: A hit, a most palpable hit.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Well, come again.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Another. Judgment.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Aye, aye grant, a touch, a touch.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Here Hamlet, the king doth drink a health to thee

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Here Hamlet, take my napkin, wipe thy face.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Give him the wine.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Set it by, I will have another bout first,
I will drink anon.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: Here Hamlet, thy mother drinks to thee.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Do not drink Gertred : O it is the poisoned cup!

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Leartes come, you dally with me,
I pray you pass with your most cunningest play.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Aye! say you so? have at you,
I will hit you now my Lord:
And yet it goes almost against my conscience.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Come on sir.

div1.stage: They catch one anothers Rapiers, and both are wounded, Leartes falles downe, the Queene falles downe and dies.

sp.speaker: King
sp.l: Look to the Queen.

sp.speaker: Queene
sp.l: O the drink, the drink, Hamlet, the drink.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Treason, ho, keep the gates.

sp.speaker: Lords
sp.l: How is it my Lord Leartes?

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: Even as a coxcomb should,
Foolishly slain with my own weapon:
Hamlet, thou hast not in thee half an hour of life,
The fatal Instrument is in thy hand.
Unbated and envenomed: thy mother is poisoned
That drink was made for thee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: The poisoned Instrument within my hand?
Then venom to thy venom, die damned villain:
Come drink, here lies thy union here.

sp.speaker: Lear.
sp.l: O he is justly served:
Hamlet, before I die, here take my hand,
And withal, my love: I do forgive thee.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: And I thee, O I am dead Horatio, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: No, I am more an antic Roman,
Than a Dane, here is some poison left.

sp.speaker: Ham.
sp.l: Upon my love I charge thee let it go,
O fie Horatio, and if thou shouldst die,
What a scandal wouldst thou leave behind?
What tongue should tell the story of our deaths,
If not from thee? O my heart sinks Horatio,
Mine eyes have lost their sight, my tongue his use:
Farewell Horatio, heaven receive my soul.

div1.stage:
Ham. dies.
Enter Voltemar and the Ambassadors from England. enter Fortenbrasse with his traine.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: Where is this bloody sight?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: If aught of woe or wonder you would behold,
Then look upon this tragic spectacle.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: O imperious death! how many Princes
Hast thou at one draft bloodily shot to death?

sp.speaker: Ambass.
sp.l: Our embassy that we have brought from England,
Where be these Princes that should hear us speak?
O most most unlooked for time! unhappy country.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.l: Content yourselves, I will show to all, the ground,
The first beginning of this Tragedy:
Let there a scaffold be reared up in the market place,
And let the State of the world be there:
Where you shall hear such a sad story told,
That never mortal man could more unfold.

sp.speaker: Fort.
sp.l: I have some rights of memory to this kingdom,
Which now to claim my leisure doth invite me:
Let four of our chiefest Captains
Bear Hamlet like a soldier to his grave:
For he was likely, had he lived,
To a proved most royal.
Take up the body, such a sight as this
Becomes the fields, but here doth much amiss.
